docs.lead_paragraph: In the blink-of-an-eye downtown that passes for the business district in this river town, the Prime Tanning leather factory is almost all there is. There is no doctor or supermarket to serve the 6,400 residents, and the town only just snared its first bank branch. ''We're the mill in the mill town,'' said Kenneth R. Purdy, Prime Tanning's president and chief executive. ''This is it, baby.''

headline.main: Troops Need Boots, So Closed Mill Will Reopen

docs.abstract: Prime Tanning leather factory in Berwick, Me, which was slated for closing, will stay open because war in Afghanistan means that more American soldiers will need combat boots, which are required by federal law to be made from American shoe leather, which only Prime Tanning and a few other companies produce; company also believes that shoemakers and retailers will be looking for more domestic suppliers because security measures will generate delays and red tape for imported goods; photos (M)
